title: Quick Fit versus Programming Hearing Aid Fittings: Acoustic and Perceptual Differences
chief_complaint: I have noticed a gradual decline in my ability to communicate over the past few years, especially in background noise and when using the telephone.

problem_summary.onset: Gradual decline over the past few years.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Difficulty in competing background noise; difficulty on the telephone.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Impacts work as a social worker and daily communication.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking assessment of hearing sensitivity and improvement in communication.

history.present_illness: Patient reports gradual hearing decline. Previous testing 30 years ago was normal.
history.noise_exposure_history: Military service, regular firearm use, occasional power tools, daily use of earbuds for music.
history.patient_goals: Assess hearing; improve communication in noise and on phone.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral symmetrical mild to moderate-severe gradually sloping sensorineural hearing loss.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs indicate mild loss consistent with PTA. Word recognition scores indicate normal ability to recognize speech at suprathreshold levels.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal ear canal volume, static admittance, and middle ear pressure (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Generally within normal limits; slightly elevated at 2000 and 4000 Hz for left ipsilateral and 4000 Hz for left contralateral stimulation.

tests.name: Hearing Aid Fitting (Quick-Fit)
tests.key_findings: Fitted with smartphone-enabled RICs with open domes and remote mic. Programmed to NAL-NL2 using manufacturer 'Quick-Fit' without Real-Ear Measurement (REM) verification at the time of fitting. Subsequent analysis showed Quick-Fit significantly under-amplified the target.

numeric_results.Target_Mismatch: Deviated from NAL-NL2 target by >10 dB at multiple frequencies

history.patient_goals: Patient wished to terminate the trial period.
history.prior_management: Hearing aids fitted at V1 using Quick-Fit protocol.

tests.name: Patient Report/Outcome
tests.key_findings: Patient reported devices did not improve ability to understand speech.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral symmetrical mild to moderate-severe sloping sensorineural hearing loss with excellent word recognition scores in quiet. Although fitted with appropriate technology (RICs with remote mic), the devices were programmed using a 'Quick-Fit' approach without real-ear verification. This resulted in under-amplification (only 60% audibility achieved vs. 84% potential with verified fitting), leading to a lack of perceived benefit and subsequent return of the devices.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a mild to moderate-severe hearing loss in both ears, which explains your difficulty in background noise.
We are recommending receiver-in-the-canal hearing aids with a remote microphone to help with distance and noise.
We will use a smartphone app to stream phone calls directly to your hearing aids to address your phone difficulties.
It is critical to verify the hearing aid settings on your ear to ensure you are getting the correct amount of sound for speech clarity.
notes_for_actor: You are a 56-year-old social worker who is motivated but skeptical.
You have a history of noise exposure (military, guns, tools, music).
At the first visit, you are agreeable to the plan.
At the follow-up visit (V2), you are disappointed and firm: the hearing aids did not help you understand speech better, and you want to return them.
You represent a patient who received a 'Quick-Fit' rather than a verified fitting, leading to a poor outcome.
